title: Stuart Bingham hits form ahead of English Open defence: ‘Something clicked’
text:
Stuart Bingham won the English Open last year (Picture: Getty Images)

Stuart Bingham has had the perfect preparation for the defence of his English Open title by winning Championship League Group Two on Thursday.

The 43-year-old came through the group stage on Wednesday thanks to wins over Gary Wilson, Jack Lisowski, Mark Selby and Ryan Day, then went on to beat Wilson again in the semis before seeing off Selby 3-1 in the final.

The victory puts Ball Run in the Championship League Winners’ Group next March where he will join Group One winner Neil Robertson.

It has been a slow start to the season for the former world champion, with his only quarter-final run so far coming at the Six-red World Championship, but he believes he has found something like his best form ahead of defending his English Open title next week.

‘Something clicked today,’ said Bingham after ousting Selby in the Leicester final. ‘My manager said “whatever you had for dinner, put it on the menu and we’ll have it all the time” because after dinner I hardly missed a ball.

Bingham had a good day in the Championship League on Friday (Picture: Getty Images)

‘I got through to the Winners’ Group last year and have won the tournament before, so it’s nice now to be able to look forward to coming back for the final group.

‘I feel like I have been playing pretty well recently. There have been a couple of bad results here and there but all-in-all beating the likes of Gary Wilson and Mark in the final shows that my game is there.’

Bingham will be looking to take this momentum into Crawley where he takes on Polish youngster Kacper Filipiak in the first round.

While he remains number 13 in the world, the Englishman is down at number 52 on the one-year list, which illustrates the tricky season he has endured so far.

The prize fund at the English Open has been increased from last year but the winner’s cheque remains £70,000.

Bingham will have plenty of competition to get his hands on the cash with the tournament extremely well attended and attracting Ronnie O’Sullivan into his first UK-based tournament of the season.

The Rocket has only competed in the Shanghai Masters so far this season but heads to Crawley as he looks to regain the title he won in 2017 when it was held in Barnsley.

O’Sullivan is in action on Monday evening in the first round against Jamie O’Neill.
